15.95.text: Fifteen years ago, it was widely assumed

18.84.text: that the vast majority of brain development

20.89.text: takes place in the first few years of life.

23.87.text: Back then, 15 years ago, we didn't have the ability

26.58.text: to look inside the living human brain

29.20.text: and track development across the lifespan.

32.24.text: In the past decade or so, mainly due to advances

37.20.text: such as magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI,

40.15.text: neuroscientists have started to look inside the living

43.27.text: human brain of all ages, and to track changes

45.69.text: in brain structure and brain function,

48.56.text: so we use structural MRI if you'd like to take a snapshot,

52.24.text: a photograph, at really high resolution of the inside

55.30.text: of the living human brain, and we can ask questions like,

58.52.text: how much gray matter does the brain contain,

60.96.text: and how does that change with age?

62.77.text: And we also use functional MRI, called fMRI,

66.48.text: to take a video, a movie, of brain activity

69.87.text: when participants are taking part in some kind of task

72.74.text: like thinking or feeling or perceiving something.

75.63.text: So many labs around the world are involved in this kind

78.40.text: of research, and we now have a really rich

80.63.text: and detailed picture of how the living human brain develops,

84.15.text: and this picture has radically changed the way

87.22.text: we think about human brain development

89.85.text: by revealing that it's not all over in early childhood,

92.62.text: and instead, the brain continues to develop

95.33.text: right throughout adolescence and into the '20s and '30s.

99.38.text: So adolescence is defined as the period of life that starts

103.36.text: with the biological, hormonal, physical changes of puberty

107.75.text: and ends at the age at which an individual attains

111.04.text: a stable, independent role in society.

116.28.text: It can go on a long time. (Laughter)

119.04.text: One of the brain regions that changes most dramatically

122.06.text: during adolescence is called prefrontal cortex.

125.33.text: So this is a model of the human brain,

128.30.text: and this is prefrontal cortex, right at the front.

131.18.text: Prefrontal cortex is an interesting brain area.

133.69.text: It's proportionally much bigger in humans than

136.81.text: in any other species, and it's involved in a whole range of

140.45.text: high level cognitive functions, things like decision-making,

143.72.text: planning, planning what you're going to do tomorrow

145.81.text: or next week or next year, inhibiting

148.55.text: inappropriate behavior, so stopping yourself saying

151.22.text: something really rude or doing something really stupid.

154.14.text: It's also involved in social interaction,

159.05.text: So MRI studies looking at the development of this region

162.10.text: have shown that it really undergoes dramatic development

167.50.text: So if you look at gray matter volume, for example,

170.46.text: gray matter volume across age from age four to 22 years

175.31.text: increases during childhood, which is what you can see

177.63.text: on this graph. It peaks in early adolescence.

181.38.text: The arrows indicate peak gray matter volume

183.95.text: in prefrontal cortex. You can see that that peak happens

187.41.text: a couple of years later in boys relative to girls,

190.92.text: and that's probably because boys go through puberty

192.76.text: a couple of years later than girls on average,

195.01.text: and then during adolescence, there's a significant decline

198.45.text: in gray matter volume in prefrontal cortex.

201.13.text: Now that might sound bad, but actually this is

203.16.text: a really important developmental process, because

206.31.text: gray matter contains cell bodies and connections

210.41.text: between cells, the synapses, and this decline

213.87.text: in gray matter volume during prefrontal cortex

216.61.text: is thought to correspond to synaptic pruning,

221.83.text: This is a really important process. It's partly dependent

224.96.text: on the environment that the animal or the human is in,

228.09.text: and the synapses that are being used are strengthened,

231.54.text: and synapses that aren't being used

233.47.text: in that particular environment are pruned away.

235.80.text: You can think of it a bit like pruning a rosebush.

238.31.text: You prune away the weaker branches so that

241.15.text: the remaining, important branches, can grow stronger,

244.19.text: and this process, which effectively fine-tunes brain tissue

250.78.text: is happening in prefrontal cortex and in other brain regions

253.70.text: during the period of human adolescence.

257.25.text: So a second line of inquiry that we use to track changes

260.95.text: in the adolescent brain is using functional MRI

264.20.text: to look at changes in brain activity across age.

267.48.text: So I'll just give you an example from my lab.

269.12.text: So in my lab, we're interested in the social brain, that is

272.68.text: the network of brain regions that we use to understand

276.26.text: other people and to interact with other people.

278.70.text: So I like to show a photograph of a soccer game

282.46.text: to illustrate two aspects of how your social brains work.

286.87.text: So this is a soccer game. (Laughter)

288.30.text: Michael Owen has just missed a goal, and he's lying

290.94.text: on the ground, and the first aspect of the social brain

293.75.text: that this picture really nicely illustrates is how automatic

296.70.text: and instinctive social emotional responses are,

299.75.text: so within a split second of Michael Owen missing this goal,

302.72.text: everyone is doing the same thing with their arms

304.53.text: and the same thing with their face, even Michael Owen

306.33.text: as he slides along the grass, is doing the same thing

308.16.text: with his arms, and presumably has a similar

310.42.text: facial expression, and the only people who don't

312.40.text: are the guys in yellow at the back — (Laughs) —

315.86.text: and I think they're on the wrong end of the stadium,

318.40.text: and they're doing another social emotional response

320.70.text: that we all instantly recognize, and that's the second aspect

323.33.text: of the social brain that this picture really nicely illustrates,

326.97.text: how good we are at reading other people's behavior,

330.35.text: their actions, their gestures, their facial expressions,

333.03.text: in terms of their underlying emotions and mental states.

336.84.text: So you don't have to ask any of these guys.

338.62.text: You have a pretty good idea of what they're feeling

341.16.text: and thinking at this precise moment in time.

343.75.text: So that's what we're interested in looking at in my lab.

345.51.text: So in my lab, we bring adolescents and adults into the lab

349.09.text: to have a brain scan, we give them some kind of task

351.48.text: that involves thinking about other people, their minds,

354.77.text: their mental states, their emotions, and one of the findings

357.67.text: that we've found several times now, as have other labs

360.51.text: around the world, is part of the prefrontal cortex called

363.73.text: medial prefrontal cortex, which is shown in blue on the slide,

366.95.text: and it's right in the middle of prefrontal cortex

369.70.text: in the midline of your head.

372.10.text: This region is more active in adolescents when they make

375.39.text: these social decisions and think about other people

377.51.text: than it is in adults, and this is actually a meta-analysis

380.31.text: of nine different studies in this area from labs around

383.55.text: the world, and they all show the same thing, that activity

386.25.text: in this medial prefrontal cortex area decreases

392.07.text: And we think that might be because adolescents and adults

394.71.text: use a different mental approach, a different

397.08.text: cognitive strategy, to make social decisions,

400.50.text: and one way of looking at that is to do behavioral studies

404.01.text: whereby we bring people into the lab and we give them

405.99.text: some kind of behavioral task, and I'll just give you

408.54.text: another example of the kind of task that we use in my lab.

411.75.text: So imagine that you're the participant in one of our

414.39.text: experiments. You come into the lab,

418.79.text: In this task, you see a set of shelves.

421.58.text: Now, there are objects on these shelves, on some of them,

424.40.text: and you'll notice there's a guy standing behind the set

427.37.text: of shelves, and there are some objects that he can't see.

430.96.text: They're occluded, from his point of view, with a kind of

435.88.text: This is the same set of shelves from his point of view.

439.36.text: Notice that there are only some objects that he can see,

442.86.text: whereas there are many more objects that you can see.

445.31.text: Now your task is to move objects around.

447.50.text: The director, standing behind the set of shelves,

449.87.text: is going to direct you to move objects around,

452.61.text: but remember, he's not going to ask you to move objects

454.50.text: that he can't see. This introduces a really interesting

458.22.text: condition whereby there's a kind of conflict

460.42.text: between your perspective and the director's perspective.

463.59.text: So imagine he tells you to move the top truck left.

466.83.text: There are three trucks there. You're going to instinctively

468.87.text: go for the white truck, because that's the top truck

471.02.text: from your perspective, but then you have to remember,

473.84.text: "Oh, he can't see that truck, so he must mean

475.90.text: me to move the blue truck," which is the top truck

478.66.text: from his perspective. Now believe it or not,

481.30.text: normal, healthy, intelligent adults like you make errors

484.25.text: about 50 percent of the time on that kind of trial.

487.39.text: They move the white truck instead of the blue truck.

490.23.text: So we give this kind of task to adolescents and adults,

493.55.text: and we also have a control condition

495.10.text: where there's no director and instead we give people a rule.

499.17.text: We tell them, okay, we're going to do exactly the same thing

501.08.text: but this time there's no director. Instead you've got to

503.92.text: ignore objects with the dark gray background.

507.12.text: You'll see that this is exactly the same condition, only

509.82.text: in the no-director condition they just have to remember

512.67.text: to apply this somewhat arbitrary rule, whereas

515.74.text: in the director condition, they have to remember

517.42.text: to take into account the director's perspective

520.96.text: in order to guide their ongoing behavior.

525.26.text: Okay, so if I just show you the percentage errors

527.87.text: in a large developmental study we did,

530.43.text: this is in a study ranging from age seven to adulthood,

533.99.text: and what you're going to see is the percentage errors

535.20.text: in the adult group in both conditions,

540.46.text: that our intelligent adults are making errors about 50 percent

543.03.text: of the time, whereas they make far fewer errors

545.75.text: when there's no director present, when they just have

547.77.text: to remember that rule of ignoring the gray background.

553.52.text: in exactly the same way. Between late childhood

558.69.text: in other words a reduction of errors, in both of these trials,

563.16.text: But it's when you compare the last two groups,

565.44.text: the mid-adolescent group and the adult group

567.40.text: where things get really interesting, because there, there is

570.56.text: no continued improvement in the no-director condition.

573.59.text: In other words, everything you need to do in order to

576.52.text: remember the rule and apply it seems to be fully developed

581.76.text: if you look at the last two gray bars, there's still

584.16.text: a significant improvement in the director condition

587.31.text: between mid-adolescence and adulthood, and what

589.75.text: this means is that the ability to take into account someone

593.12.text: else's perspective in order to guide ongoing behavior,

596.41.text: which is something, by the way, that we do in everyday life all

603.27.text: So if you have a teenage son or a daughter and you

605.81.text: sometimes think they have problems taking other people's

608.22.text: perspectives, you're right. They do. And this is why.

611.98.text: So we sometimes laugh about teenagers.

615.49.text: They're parodied, sometimes even demonized in the media

619.36.text: for their kind of typical teenage behavior. They take risks,

622.88.text: they're sometimes moody, they're very self-conscious.

625.65.text: I have a really nice anecdote from a friend of mine

628.15.text: who said that the thing he noticed most

630.63.text: about his teenage daughters before and after puberty

633.61.text: was their level of embarrassment in front of him.

635.87.text: So, he said, "Before puberty, if my two daughters

638.36.text: were messing around in a shop, I'd say, 'Hey,

640.62.text: stop messing around and I'll sing your favorite song,'

642.37.text: and instantly they'd stop messing around and he'd sing

644.27.text: their favorite song. After puberty, that became the threat.

649.56.text: The very notion of their dad singing in public

653.03.text: was enough to make them behave.

656.82.text: "Well, is adolescence a kind of recent phenomenon?

659.46.text: Is it something we've invented recently in the West?"

664.25.text: of descriptions of adolescence in history that sound

701.41.text: So almost 400 years ago, Shakespeare was portraying

704.34.text: adolescents in a very similar light to the light that we

707.06.text: portray them in today, but today we try to understand

710.52.text: their behavior in terms of the underlying changes

715.55.text: So for example, take risk-taking. We know that adolescents

719.15.text: have a tendency to take risks. They do.

721.48.text: They take more risks than children or adults,

724.11.text: and they are particularly prone to taking risks

726.57.text: when they're with their friends. There's an important drive

729.54.text: to become independent from one's parents

732.02.text: and to impress one's friends in adolescence.

734.85.text: But now we try to understand that in terms of

737.45.text: the development of a part of their brain called the limbic system,

740.44.text: so I'm going to show you the limbic system in red

742.98.text: in the slide behind me, and also on this brain.

744.85.text: So the limbic system is right deep inside the brain,

747.96.text: and it's involved in things like emotion processing

751.69.text: and reward processing. It gives you the rewarding feeling

754.84.text: out of doing fun things, including taking risks.

758.14.text: It gives you the kick out of taking risks.

760.50.text: And this region, the regions within the limbic system,

763.55.text: have been found to be hypersensitive to the rewarding

766.97.text: feeling of risk-taking in adolescents compared with adults,

770.74.text: and at the very same time, the prefrontal cortex,

774.44.text: which you can see in blue in the slide here,

776.71.text: which stops us taking excessive risks,

779.58.text: is still very much in development in adolescents.
